commit.message:
egl-wayland: implement linux-drm-syncobj-v1

This implements the explicit sync linux-drm-syncobj-v1 protocol for EGL.

Most of this change involves wayland-protocol handling boilerplate. The
protocol works by allowing the creation of timelines (i.e. DRM syncobjs)
and per-surface states. We can then specify acquire and release points
during our surface state configuration which will tell the compositor
when it can access the buffer or notify us when it is finished accessing
the buffer.

Sync point signaling takes place during acquire_surface_image. We choose
our two release point values and send them to the compositor.  In the
acquire case, the EGLSync will be created first and will be populated
with a fence representing the GPU work. We can extract its syncfd and
import it at the acquire point. We choose the release point during
image acquisition, but don't actually create an EGLSync for it until
later when the compositor has added a fence to the release point. We
check if this has taken place after every surface commit.

Separate timelines are used for the acquire and release points. Each
stream image will have its own timeline, otherwise our signaling of
acquire points would implicitly signal the still-pending release points.
egl-wayland: Fix potential null-pointer dereference

egl-wayland: Read compositor device from zwp_linux_dmabuf_v1

Compositors start dropping support for wl_drm because it is replaced by linux-dmabuf.
See https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/wlroots/wlroots/-/commit/2f2a55ebd3c5a950f1bf8c280edf0838721363da.
Try reading compositors main device from linux-dmabuf v4 if supported and otherwise fallback to wl_drm.
bump version to 1.1.13

egl-wayland: Make sure that the EGLDevice search matches the right device node

In checkNvidiaDrmDevice, while we've got the device open, call
drmGetDevice and make sure that wlEglGetPlatformDisplayExport is
matching the render node, regardless of whether the server sends back
the render or primary node.

egl-wayland: Exit early from eglGetPlatformDisplay for non-NV devices

In wlEglGetPlatformDisplayExport, after we get the DRM device node from
the server, call drmGetDevice to check if it points to an NVIDIA device.

If it's not an NVIDIA device, then return early before calling
eglQueryDevicesEXT.

If the display is configured to use GPU offloading (either with
EGL_EXT_explicit_device or if __NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD is set), then it
will still continue and look for a matching/NVIDIA device regardless of
what the server is running.

On multi-GPU systems, calling eglQueryDevicesEXT can cause it to power
the GPU's on, which can take a very long time.

egl-wayland: Include internal header files in "make dist".

For the autotools build, add the various internal header files to
libnvidia_egl_wayland_la_SOURCES so that "make dist" include them in the
archive.

egl-wayland: receive dmabuf v4 feedback events on surface queues

Currently, egl-wayland receives dmabuf v4 feedback events on it's
per-EGLDisplay queue. These events are dispatched after a new EGLSurface is
created or an existing surface is reallocated. The former is fine because
the compositor will always send the initial feedback immediately after
surface creation. However, if the feedback changes in response to the
surface being resized (e.g. if it is made full-screen and becomes eligible
for direct scan-out) then the new feedback will not be sent until a buffer
with the new size is attached. This doesn't happen until the next
eglSwapBuffers call. Therefore we won't actually receive the new batch of
feedback events, they will just sit in the queue.

Not only does this entirely defeat the purpose of supporting the dmabuf v4
protocol, if a surface is destroyed those pending events may still be
dispatched afterwards, leading to a use-after-free.

To fix this, instead of receiving dmabuf v4 feedback events on the display
queue, we will instead receive them on the surface queue. Since this queue
gets dispatched every frame, we will be guaranteed to always have an
up-to-date set of tranches.

egl-wayland: handle multiple tranches for the same device

To determine the set of format modifiers to use when creating a surface
we will find the first tranche for our DRM device, or else the
compositor's main device, and then look for our DRM format in that
tranche's list of formats to find the modifier list. If our format is
not in the list, then we won't use explicit modifiers when creating the
surface.

However, some compositors will advertise multiple tranches for a given
DRM device with a different set of formats in each one. Kwin is one
example. In that case, the tranche we select above might not contain our
format, but it could still be in one of the other tranches for the same
device.

Instead of simply picking the first tranche for the desired device, with
this change we will loop over the format list of each of that device's
tranches until we find a tranche that contains the format we want.

egl-wayland: destroy all proxies before destroying their queues

The latest version of libwayland-client.so will print a warning if a
queue is destroyed while a proxy is still assigned to it. This warning
is triggered during EGL termination by our linux_dmabuf object and the
default dmabuf feedback object for the display. It is also triggered
during EGLSurface destruction by the surface's dmabuf feedback object.
That last object never gets destroyed at all, in fact.

This change ensures that the above objects are all destroyed *before*
their queues.
bump version to 1.1.12

egl-wayland: set unprocessedFeedback flag

A prior commit added logic to reallocate window surfaces after receiving
a new dma-buf feedback from the compositor. This keys off of the
unprocessedFeedback flag, however currently that flag never actually
gets set. This change sets the flag after receiving a new feedback, so
that we will reallocate the surface on the next eglSwapBuffers call.

wayland: Use linear modifier for prime when appropriate

Originally we removed forcing the linear modifier when running prime
since we could count on finding the linear modifier somewhere in the
list of intel/AMD modifiers. However with dmabuf v4 we will look for
a tranche of modifiers for a specific device (the NV one) and use the
modifiers for that. A non-fullscreen app in a wayland prime setup may
only get one tranche for the main device, meaning it finds no modifiers
to initialize the consumer with.

This change goes back to explicitly specifying the linear modifier for
prime. This happens with prime enabled and when:
1. We are on an older protocol version (< 4). This is done just to be
   explicit.
2. We could not find a format set for this device.
Fix wrong destruction order for event queue
Destroy all created wayland object in terminateDisplay

egl-wayland: Fix indentation problems

This change fixes the indentation problems introduced by CL 31917963.

wayland: Only search dmabuf format sets if surface has an eglConfig

This fixes a vulkan wsi regression on wayland introduced by CL 32234950.
Vulkan surfaces will not have a defined eglConfig, and therefore we
cannot check what format they would like to use.

Eventually we need to fix this and plumb modifier selection through on
vulkan, however given the way we currently sit vulkan on top of EGL this
will not be a simple fix. This change is intended as a short-term
bandaid to fix the regression while allowing GL/EGL to continue using
dmabuf v4.

wayland: Register per-surface feedback

This adds the final piece of dynamic modifier renegotiation on wayland.
This change gets a feedback object for the surface that the compositor
will use to send us updates on supported formats/modifiers.

This is important for enabling features such as direct dGPU scanout
on wayland. Currently we use a linear modifier when running in PRIME, but
with this change we can also react to the compositor sending us dGPU
scanout modifiers if we are fullscreened.

wayland: Realloc surface if the compositor sends updated feedback

In the case of on-the-fly negotiation with a compositor that supports
dmabuf v4, we may get an updated set of modifiers that we need to
react to. This turns wlEglResizeSurfaceIfRequired into
wlEglReallocSurfaceIfRequired, which checks if we need to reallocate
the surface and does so.

Note that this functionality is really for per-surface feedback objects,
where the compositor can resend scanout tranches if the surface is
fullscreen. This CL adds the ability to realloc before we enable
per-surface feedback, since per-surface feedback tells the compositor
we support dynamically reallocating the surface to follow what it
sends.

wayland: Implement linux_dmabuf protocol v4

This adds basic support for the dmabuf v4 protocol implementation,
which adds compositor feedback objects to get hints about what modifiers
to use when allocating surfaces. This is only a basic implementation,
with the fancy per-surface and reallocation bits coming in following
changes.

This also adds all of the structs we will use to handle feedback. A feedback
object holds a list of tranches sent by the compositor. Each tranche has
a dev_t device and a set of format/modifiers supported for that device.

wayland: Add dmabuf format set

This adds helper functions for handling sets of dmabuf formats and
their associated modifiers. This will be needed for later dmabuf
v4 feedback structs, where we have multiple places to handle lists
of formats and want to be able to share code.

This adds the WlEglDmaBufFormatSet struct, and a couple functions
for easily interacting with it. This is mostly all existing
functionality from our current dmabuf protocol implementation, just
wrapped up in a reusable struct.

wayland: Fix dmabuf protocol registration

Currently we are registering our listener for the dmabuf protocol
in dmabuf_set_interface. This is called when we make a new registry
on a wl_proxy wrapper for our wl_display in wlEglInitializeHook.

The issue is that dmabuf_handle_modifier is never called. The
compositor will send the event, but the client library will never
deliver it to us even though we have bound the protocol and registered
a listener. I'm not sure exactly why this is, but it has something
to do with the proxy wrapper we are using. Other handlers, such as
for eglstreams, bind the registry but defer adding a listener until
after we have finished dealing with the wrapper.

This change makes linux_dmabuf add a listener after the registry
globals have been enumerated. This makes dmabuf_handle_modifier
finally start getting called and populating our drm format list.

It also actually passes the modifiers we received from the compositor
to streamImageConsumerConnect. This is needed for future work on
dynamic modifier renegotiation.

egl-wayland: Merge two identical if-statements

Two if-statements with identical conditions in wlEglDestroySurface()
function are merged into one.

egl-wayland: Expose the functionality of the presentation-time protocol

The following functions are added and exposed to the users of this
library:

wlEglPostPresentExport2: An updated version of wlEglPostPresentExport
that expects a pointer to a __GLNVpresentEventInfoRec structure. If the
pointer is not NULL and the compositor supports the presentation-time
extension, a presentation-time feedback request is sent along with the
presentation request and the pointer is passed as a parameter to the
callback functions that process the feedback events. In the callback
functions, the status field of these structures are updated to indicate
that the requested presentation has been performed.

wlEglProcessPresentationFeedbacksExport: A non-blocking function to
dispatch all received presentation feedback events on demand. Returns
the number of updated presentation event information structures.

wlEglWaitAllPresentationFeedbacksExport: A blocking function that waits
for all events corresponding to the sent feedback requests to be
received. Designed to be explicitly called before destroying
WlEglSurface objects to prevent events to be placed to a destroyed event
queue. There are several reasons for this operation to be implemented as
a separate function that is exposed to the users:
  * It is possible for the clients of this library to destroy the
    resources passed to wlEglPostPresentExport2 function before they
    destroy the corresponding WlEglSurface.
  * Clients of this library could use a counter that counts the number
    of presentation requests sent and the return value of the
    wlEglProcessPresentationFeedbacksExport function to wait for all in
    flight presentation feedback requests. However, they are allowed to
    change the number of presentation requests they expect by choosing to
    ignore some results, creating a disparity between the number of in
    flight requests and expected number of updates.

egl-wayland: Add presentation-time protocol files

Wayland's presentation-time protocol is used to receive presentation
timing information from a compositor that supports it. This change adds
the client side header file and the glue code used by this protocol to
let egl-wayland to employ this protocol.

egl-wayland: Add wlEglCreateSurfaceExport2 function

Since there is a need to create a surface with specific attributes and
the existing wlEglCreateSurfaceExport() function does not take an
attribute list as a parameter, a new version of this function is created
that takes an attribute list to keep the API/ABI compatibility.

EGL/Wayland: Disable NV -> NV offloading with EGL_EXT_explicit_device

Disallow offloading between NVIDIA devices for Wayland, because it's
currently broken in both Weston and Mutter.

With Weston, it doesn't work because Weston will try to use the image
for overlay or scanout, which doesn't work with a pitch linear sysmem
image due to bug 3770050.

Mutter doesn't correctly handle external-only images, so it'll try to
import the EGLImage into a GL_TEXTURE_2D texture, which also fails.

EGL/Wayland: Fix matching EGL_DEVICE_EXT attributes in existing displays

In the EGL Wayland library, record the EGL_DEVICE_EXT attribute in the
WlEglDisplayRec struct.

In wlEglGetPlatformDisplayExport, record the EGL_DEVICE_EXT attribute in
a new WlEglDisplayRec::requestedDevice field, and check that the device
matches when searching for an existing EGLDisplay.

Previously, two calls to eglGetPlatformDisplay with the same wl_display
pointer but different EGL_DEVICE_EXT attributes would use return the
same EGLDisplay.

EGL/Wayland: Implement EGL_EXT_explicit_device

Update the wayland platform library to handle EGL_EXT_explicit_device.

If the caller passes in an EGL_DEVICE_EXT attribute to
eglGetPlatformDisplay, then wlEglGetPlatformDisplayExport will now try
to use that device.

Reworked how __NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD is handled. Now, if
__NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD is set, and it didn't already select an
EGLDeviceEXT handle to use for rendering (either using wl_drm or an
EGL_DEVICE_EXT attribute), then it will pick an NVIDIA device instead of
failing.

If __NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD is set, then it will now prefer the device
from the EGL_DEVICE_EXT attribute, then the server device, then whatever
device shows up first.

In addition, if __NV_PRIME_RENDER_OFFLOAD is set, but it ends up using
the same device as the compositor anyway, then it will no longer try to
use the rendering offloading path.
bump version to 1.1.11
